page.title: 06FARMING V WILDLIFE
page.content:
The use of large agricultural machinery has inevitably led to the loss of farm hedgerows. On the largest farm in this area an average-sized field is 73 acres. To compensate for this loss 25,000 evergreen and mixed deciduous trees have been planted in suitable locations around the farm. These also afford some cover for the 200 pheasants reared and released on to the land each year.
Most of the local farmers rear pheasants and organise shoots in autumn and winter. These are an important social event in the farming community.
Stainton Wood (owned by a local woodyard) is also used for this purpose.
